ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained a deeper understanding of the particulars of Russian grammar and learned about Russian culture.
I learned how to speak some Russian.

Russian 120 was an incredible course. I really feel like I learned a lot and have a decent grasp on the language after only one year. I like the format of the class, the daily homework, bi-weekly tests, and oral examinations. Overall, one of my most enjoyable classes!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Great class, super big time commitment sometimes too much, unexpected levels of involvement were needed.

Perhaps do not make the quizzes for a grade, just for practice. I like that the course revolves around a textbook, as it makes it easier to go back and review the grammar we have learned. That being said, I think sometimes the textbooks can be confusingly formatted (such that we end up learning similar concepts spread out over several chapters) and it can be hard to tie everything together. One example of this consists of the various time constructions. In addition, I think it would be helpful if there was more actual drilling of the endings in class.

I enjoyed Russian this semester, and I really feel that I'm starting to get a grasp on the language. I found it especially rewarding when we would review a certain sentence model (such as an "if-then-because" sentence), and then orally work through all of its variations in class. These types of exercises really helped me develop an understanding of the specific grammatical tool we were learning that day. However, as with last semester, I found the emphasis on memorization and acting to tedious, time consuming, and stressful for little benefit. Personally, I don't find memorizing poems to be a particularly effective way of learning a language when actual spontaneous dialogue serves a similar function while being far more practical.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! Will make one fall in love with Russian.
Yes, but only if they want to work hard.
I would definitely recommend this class to anyone who likes languages! Russian is especially fun to learn because it is so different than anything else, and oftentimes can feel like a puzzle.
